original_period_characterizations.topic_label: Geometric Feature Analysis and Invariant Recognition
original_period_characterizations.topic_description: This paradigm centered on extracting geometric features and moment invariants for pattern recognition, as seen in 'Visual pattern recognition by moment invariants' (1962) and 'Use of the Hough transformation to detect lines and curves in pictures' (1972), emphasizing mathematical robustness against transformations. It also incorporated psychophysical studies like 'Looking at upside-down faces' (1969) to understand perceptual constraints, aligning with the broader goal of modeling human-like visual processing through computational methods.

representative_papers.title: The neural mechanism of binocular depth discrimination
representative_papers.abstract:
The article explores the neural mechanisms of binocular depth discrimination in the cat's primary visual cortex, revealing that stimuli correctly positioned in both eyes elicit stronger responses than monocular stimuli, and highlighting the role of vertical and horizontal disparities in depth perception. This research provides insights into the basic mechanisms underlying depth discrimination in animals.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, animal cognition, machine learning, visual science, image analysis, stereoscopic processing, neuroscience, binocular depth discrimination, cognitive science, object orientation, depth map, computational imaging, localization, deep learning, shift detection, machine vision, computer stereo vision, computer vision

representative_papers.title: Visual pattern recognition by moment invariants
representative_papers.abstract:
This article presents a theory of two-dimensional moment invariants for recognizing planar geometric figures, establishing a fundamental theorem that connects these invariants to well-known algebraic forms. It discusses the derivation of complete systems under various transformations and demonstrates practical applications in visual pattern recognition, including the ability to identify geometric patterns and alphabetical characters regardless of their position, size, or orientation.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, object recognition, computer vision, visual pattern recognition, cognitive science, temporal pattern recognition, visual perception, vision recognition, machine vision, moment invariants

representative_papers.title: The Discrimination of Visual Number
representative_papers.abstract:
The article explores the concept of "numerousness," which refers to the ability to discern the relative quantity of objects in a collection without counting them, and discusses various methods of making such judgments, including comparative and absolute assessments. It also touches on the implications of visual perception and reasoning in understanding numerical discrimination in cognitive science and psychology.

Topic: visual number, visual reasoning, inference, computer vision, variant interpretation, cognitive science, visual perception, demography, statistics, psychology, numeracy, disparity

representative_papers.title: A Simple Method of Resolution of a Distribution into Gaussian Components
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses a method for resolving complex biological distributions, particularly in morphometric studies of fish populations, into Gaussian components to better understand the underlying frequency distributions associated with different species or age groups. It critiques previous smoothing techniques and emphasizes the importance of fitting normal curves to the observed data to accurately identify and analyze these components.

Topic: bayesian analysis, spectral theory, gaussian process, image analysis, high-dimensional statistics, gaussian analysis, geometrical accuracy, computational imaging, gaussian components, partial evaluation, simple method, biostatistics, statistics, machine learning research, machine vision, digital image processing, computer vision, applied mathematics, time series, reproducing kernel method

representative_papers.title: Looking at upside-down faces.
representative_papers.abstract:
The article explores how individuals recognize and remember faces compared to other familiar objects that are typically viewed from a single orientation, specifically examining the effects of presenting these images upside-down on memory performance. It delves into the implications for visual perception and recognition systems in fields such as computer vision and facial recognition.

Topic: image analysis, ophthalmology, computer vision, visual system, facial reconstruction, visual perception, facial plastic surgery, visual science, facial recognition system, machine vision, face detection, facial expression recognition, aesthetics

representative_papers.title: Two Visual Systems
representative_papers.abstract:
The article explores the visual systems in the hamster brain, focusing on how ablation of cortical or tectal areas affects visual localization and discrimination blindness. It also touches on broader themes related to visual modeling, perception, and various applications in visual arts and computing.

Topic: visual modeling, visual arts, information visualization, visual reasoning, visual communication, visual computing, computer vision, visualization, cognitive science, visual system, visual perception, visual science, machine vision, visual processing

representative_papers.title: Use of the Hough transformation to detect lines and curves in pictures
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the Hough transformation, a computationally efficient method for detecting lines and curves in images, highlighting the advantages of using angle-radius parameters over traditional slope-intercept forms. It also explores the broader applications of this technique in curve fitting and its implications for various fields such as computer vision, image analysis, and pattern recognition.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, visual science, image analysis, neuroscience, object detection, image representation, hough transformation, computational imaging, computational geometry, localization, shift detection, machine vision, digital image processing, curve fitting, object recognition, computer vision, curve modeling, applied mathematics

representative_papers.title: Textural Features for Image Classification
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the significance of textural features in image classification, detailing easily computable features based on gray-tone spatial dependencies and their application in categorizing various types of imagery, including photomicrographs and satellite images. It presents experimental results demonstrating high identification accuracy across different datasets, suggesting the broad applicability of these textural features in image classification tasks.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, computational imaging, content-based image retrieval, image classification, object recognition, computer vision, multimedia retrieval, feature detection, deep learning, image representation, machine learning research, texture analysis, textural features, machine vision, digital image processing

original_period_characterizations.topic_label: Geometric Feature Analysis and Invariant Recognition
original_period_characterizations.topic_description: This paradigm centered on geometric feature extraction and invariant recognition, emphasizing the use of edge detection, stereo disparity, and photometric stereo to model surface properties and spatial relationships, as seen in the Theory of edge detection (1980), Cooperative Computation of Stereo Disparity (1976), and Photometric Method For Determining Surface Orientation From Multiple Images (1980). It also incorporated probabilistic models like Gibbs Random Fields for image segmentation, reflecting a focus on structural and invariant representations of visual data.

representative_papers.title: A Comparative Study of Texture Measures for Terrain Classification
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a comparative study of three standard approaches for automatic texture classification in terrain analysis, focusing on features derived from the Fourier power spectrum, second-order gray level statistics, and first-order statistics differences. The findings indicate that while one approach generally performed poorly, the other methods yielded comparable results in classifying terrain samples.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, machine learning, comparative study, automatic classification, image analysis, image representation, computational imaging, earth science, machine vision, digital image processing, texture measures, computer vision, geography, comparative analysis, texture analysis, image similarity, image classification, terrain classification

representative_papers.title: Theory of edge detection
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a theory of edge detection that analyzes intensity changes in images across various scales using second derivative Gaussian filters, leading to the identification of zero-crossing segments as oriented primitives. It further discusses how these segments, derived from surface discontinuities, can be combined to create a raw primal sketch, providing insights into image representation and psychophysical findings in the context of computer vision and image analysis.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, machine vision, graph theory, edge detection, theoretical computer science, computer vision, applied mathematics, feature detection, object detection, localization, systems engineering, image representation, spectral theory, detection technique, image segmentation, convex analysis

representative_papers.title: Cooperative Computation of Stereo Disparity
representative_papers.abstract:
This article explores the computation of stereo disparity by establishing correspondences between two images, presenting a cooperative algorithm that effectively extracts information from random-dot stereograms, and discussing its implications for psychophysics and the visual system.

Topic: image analysis, computer science, computer vision, digital image processing, disparity, information fusion, cooperative computation, computational imaging, 3d vision, computer stereo vision, stereo imaging, multi-view geometry, machine vision, stereoscopic processing, stereo disparity

representative_papers.title: Modeling and Segmentation of Noisy and Textured Images Using Gibbs Random Fields
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces a novel method for modeling and segmenting noisy textured images using Gibbs Random Fields, focusing on hierarchical Gibbs distributions and dynamic programming algorithms based on the maximum a posteriori criterion. It also addresses computational challenges by proposing sub-optimal approximations and presents a parameter estimation technique, supported by examples demonstrating the effectiveness of the proposed approach in image analysis and processing.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, computational imaging, information fusion, gibbs random fields, computer vision, machine learning, multimedia retrieval, image sequence analysis, data science, image representation, image segmentation, machine learning research, image denoising, markov chain monte carlo, image classification, digital image processing

representative_papers.title: The Laplacian Pyramid as a Compact Image Code
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a novel image encoding technique using the Laplacian Pyramid, which employs local operators of varying scales to achieve data compression by removing pixel-to-pixel correlations and quantizing the difference image. This iterative process enhances salient features and is well-suited for analysis tasks, supported by fast algorithms for coding and decoding.

Topic: computational imaging, computer science, image coding, compact image code, computer vision, laplacian pyramid

representative_papers.title: Fractal-Based Description of Natural Scenes
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the use of fractal functions to effectively represent and compute natural shapes in images, such as mountains and trees, by modeling their surfaces. It highlights the advantages of fractals in generating realistic textures and their applications in image analysis, scene understanding, and pattern recognition.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, image analysis, fractal, scene modeling, data science, fractal-based description, image representation, computational imaging, scene understanding, localization, deep learning, machine vision, digital image processing, scene interpretation, computer vision, geography, scene analysis, image sequence analysis, natural scenes

representative_papers.title: Photometric Method For Determining Surface Orientation From Multiple Images
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces a novel photometric stereo technique that determines surface orientation from multiple images by varying the direction of incident illumination while keeping the viewing angle constant. This method leverages radiance values from a single location to provide sufficient information for surface orientation analysis, with applications illustrated through synthesized examples.

Topic: image analysis, computational imaging, computer science, photometric method, image formation, multiple images, surface orientation, multi-view geometry, computer vision, biometrics, image representation, planetary sciences, geometry processing, photometric stereo, machine vision, digital image processing, digital photogrammetry

representative_papers.title: Model of human visual-motion sensing
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a model for human visual-motion sensing that incorporates psychophysical constraints, detailing a two-stage process involving spatial-frequency-tuned, direction-selective sensors that encode motion direction and resolve motion components across various frequencies. This model is supported by examples such as apparent motion and coherent gratings, aligning with qualitative perceptions of motion.

representative_papers.title: Face recognition: features versus templates
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses two new algorithms for computer-based face recognition: one that utilizes geometrical features of the face and another that employs gray-level template matching. Testing results indicate that the feature-based algorithm achieves approximately 90% accuracy in recognizing faces.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, computational imaging, machine vision, image classification, object recognition, feature extraction, computer vision, machine learning, feature detection, biometrics, image representation, face recognition, machine learning research, design, feature (computer vision)

representative_papers.title: Example-based learning for view-based human face detection
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses an example-based learning method for detecting vertical frontal views of human faces in complex environments, utilizing model clusters of "face" and "nonface" patterns. It emphasizes the importance of a distance metric in computing feature vectors and clusters for effective classification of face presence in images.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, human-computer interaction, explanation-based learning, computer vision, machine learning, instance-based learning, machine vision, face detection, example-based learning

representative_papers.title: Rapid Automated Algorithm for Aligning and Reslicing PET Images
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a rapid automated algorithm for the three-dimensional alignment and reslicing of PET images, utilizing voxel-by-voxel analysis to minimize variance without the need for external fiducial markers. Validation studies demonstrate its effectiveness in aligning images from various positions with minimal positional errors, making it a valuable tool for retrospective analysis in medical imaging.

representative_papers.title: <title>QBIC project: querying images by content, using color, texture, and shape</title>
representative_papers.abstract:
The QBIC project focuses on developing methods for querying large online image databases based on content attributes such as color, texture, and shape. It explores applications in various fields, including medicine and photojournalism, and discusses algorithms and systems for effective image retrieval and analysis.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, computational imaging, content-based image retrieval, image search, image retrieval, computer vision, visualization, multimedia retrieval, visual question answering, querying images, multimedia information processing, image representation, machine vision, digital image processing, image database

representative_papers.title: A flexible new technique for camera calibration
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a new flexible technique for camera calibration that requires only a planar pattern observed from at least two different orientations, allowing for free movement without needing to know the motion. This method, which models radial lens distortion and employs a closed-form solution followed by nonlinear refinement, demonstrates promising results in both simulations and real-world applications, making it a more accessible alternative to traditional calibration methods.

Topic: computer science, calibration, computer vision, camera calibration

representative_papers.title: High confidence visual recognition of persons by a test of statistical independence
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a novel method for rapid visual recognition of individuals using statistical independence tests, focusing on the unique texture of the iris in facial images. By encoding iris features into compact "iris codes" and employing statistical decision theory, the system achieves high identification accuracy and confidence levels, with a theoretical error rate of one in 131,000.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, statistical independence, computer vision, visual diagnosis, biometrics, biostatistics, visual perception, statistics, image representation, image similarity, human identification, vision recognition, machine vision, face detection

representative_papers.title: Texture analysis and classification with tree-structured wavelet transform
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a multiresolution texture analysis and classification method using a modified tree-structured wavelet transform, which allows for focused decomposition of natural textures modeled as quasi-periodic signals. This approach is contrasted with conventional pyramid-structured methods, highlighting its computational efficiency and superior performance in texture classification tasks.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, computational imaging, image classification, tree-structured wavelet transform, object recognition, computer vision, object categorization, wavelet, image representation, texture analysis, machine learning research, automatic classification, machine vision, digital image processing

representative_papers.title: Geometric invariance in computer vision
representative_papers.abstract:
The article explores the concept of geometric invariance in computer vision, covering foundational theories such as algebraic invariants and their applications in object recognition, model matching, and 3D imaging. It includes contributions from various researchers on topics like projective geometry, noise-resistant curves, and the use of moment-based recognition techniques.

Topic: geometric invariance, computer science, computer vision

original_period_characterizations.topic_description: This paradigm is characterized by the integration of deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to build hierarchical feature representations, as exemplified by R-CNN (2014) and Faster R-CNN (2015), which leverage CNNs for region proposals and object detection. It emphasizes supervised pre-training and fine-tuning, as seen in R-CNN, and the use of advanced architectures like FCNs (2015) and PSPNet (2017) for semantic segmentation and scene parsing, demonstrating a shift from traditional hand-crafted features to data-driven feature learning.

representative_papers.title: Rich Feature Hierarchies for Accurate Object Detection and Semantic Segmentation
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a novel algorithm, R-CNN, that significantly enhances object detection and semantic segmentation performance on the PASCAL VOC dataset by over 30% compared to previous methods. It leverages high-capacity convolutional neural networks for region proposals and emphasizes the benefits of supervised pre-training with domain-specific fine-tuning, providing insights into the learned feature hierarchies.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, machine learning, fuzzy set, image analysis, information fusion, accurate object detection, feature detection, cognitive science, object detection, data science, object categorization, computational imaging, localization, deep learning, machine vision, rich feature hierarchies, semantic segmentation, object recognition, computer vision, scene analysis

representative_papers.title: Fully convolutional networks for semantic segmentation
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the development and application of fully convolutional networks (FCNs) for semantic segmentation, demonstrating that these networks can outperform state-of-the-art methods by processing images of arbitrary sizes and producing correspondingly-sized outputs. It highlights the architecture's ability to combine features from different layers for improved segmentation accuracy and its effectiveness on various benchmark datasets.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, machine learning, image segmentation, image analysis, information fusion, convolutional neural network, convolutional networks, cognitive science, data science, computational imaging, scene understanding, deep learning, machine learning research, machine vision, semantic segmentation, medical image computing, feature extraction, computer vision, scene analysis

representative_papers.title: Faster R-CNN: Towards Real-Time Object Detection with Region Proposal Networks
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces Faster R-CNN, a novel object detection framework that utilizes Region Proposal Networks (RPN) to generate high-quality object proposals with minimal computational cost, significantly improving detection speed and accuracy. By integrating full-image convolutional features and leveraging neural attention mechanisms, the system achieves state-of-the-art performance on benchmark datasets while maintaining a real-time frame rate.

Topic: vehicular technology, computer science, deep learning, pattern recognition, information fusion, machine vision, object detection, scene understanding, object recognition, region proposal networks, computational imaging, machine learning, localization, data science, computer vision, cognitive science, object tracking, scene analysis, image analysis

representative_papers.title: Interactive graph cuts for optimal boundary & region segmentation of objects in N-D images
representative_papers.abstract:
This article presents a novel technique for interactive segmentation of N-dimensional images using graph cuts, allowing users to define object and background pixels to achieve optimal boundary and region segmentation. The method incorporates both hard and soft constraints, demonstrating effectiveness in various applications such as photo editing and medical imaging, while also showcasing a fast implementation through a max-flow algorithm.

Topic: computer science, computer vision, n-d images, interactive graph cuts, image segmentation, region segmentation

representative_papers.title: Faster R-CNN: towards real-time object detection with region proposal networks
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces Faster R-CNN, a novel object detection framework that utilizes Region Proposal Networks (RPN) to generate high-quality region proposals with minimal computational cost, significantly improving detection speed and accuracy. By sharing convolutional features across the network, the system achieves state-of-the-art performance on benchmark datasets while maintaining a frame rate of 5fps using a deep VGG-16 model.

Topic: computer science, information fusion, vehicular technology, scene analysis, cognitive science, data science, deep learning, pattern recognition, machine learning, computer vision, object recognition, computational imaging, object detection, scene understanding, object tracking, region proposal networks, machine vision, image analysis, localization

representative_papers.title: Delving Deep into Rectifiers: Surpassing Human-Level Performance on ImageNet Classification
representative_papers.abstract:
The article explores advancements in rectifier networks for image classification, introducing the Parametric Linear Unit (PReLU) to enhance model fitting with minimal computational cost and risk of overfitting. It also presents a robust initialization method for training deep models, achieving a groundbreaking 4.94% top-5 test error on the ImageNet 2012 dataset, surpassing human-level performance for the first time.

Topic: digital image processing, sparse neural network, imagenet classification, computer science, machine learning research, deep learning, machine vision, adversarial machine learning, image representation, human-level performance, human image synthesis, computational imaging, geometric learning, machine learning, data science, computer vision, cognitive science, computational intelligence, convolutional neural network, image analysis

representative_papers.title: Focal Loss for Dense Object Detection
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces Focal Loss, a novel approach to address the extreme class imbalance in dense object detection, which hinders the performance of one-stage detectors. By reshaping the standard cross-entropy loss to down-weight well-classified examples, the proposed method enhances the training of RetinaNet, enabling it to achieve state-of-the-art accuracy while maintaining high speed.

Topic: digital image processing, computer science, deep learning, pattern recognition, focal loss, information fusion, machine vision, object detection, image representation, scene understanding, object recognition, computational imaging, dense object detection, localization, data science, computer vision, cognitive science, multi-view geometry, object tracking, image analysis

representative_papers.title: Pyramid Scene Parsing Network
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the Pyramid Scene Parsing Network (PSPNet), which enhances scene parsing by leveraging global context information through a pyramid pooling module, achieving state-of-the-art performance in various datasets, including top rankings in the ImageNet challenge and PASCAL VOC benchmarks. The method demonstrates significant improvements in pixel-level prediction accuracy, with a record mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) of 85.4% on the Cityscapes dataset.
